Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing Records of Hydroclimate Variability in the Southeastern United States from the Middle Holocene to Present-Day
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Southeastern United States is an important agricultural region, but recent flooding and drought events have caused billions of dollars in economic loss. There is a lack of understanding about what drives changes in precipitation-evaporation (hydroclimate) trends, in part because there are fewer paleoclimate records from this region compared to the rest of the United States. This project will collect sediment cores from four lakes, two in northern Georgia and Alabama and two in the south. These regions are expected to respond differently depending on what predominantly controls hydroclimate. This project will establish if these lakes have records that are suitable for further, in-depth study of the past 5000 years and can ultimately identify what is an important control of hydroclimate and how it changed through time.
This projectâ€™s central hypothesis is that from 4000 years BP onwards, hydroclimate in the Southeastern United States has been predominantly controlled by the Pacific North American pattern which manifests as a precipitation dipole at the selected study sites. This project will focus attention on: 1) dating the collected sediment sequences from depocenter and transect cores, 2) establishing whether sediment accumulation is sufficient enough to test the hypothesis, and 3) documenting the stratigraphic sequences in the collected cores. Preliminary work on physical (grain size), geochemical (carbon and nitrogen), and biological (pollen) parameters in the sediments will also establish the feasibility of pursuing additional study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to determine if sediment from several lakes could provide long-term context on when and why precipitation-evaporation balance (hydroclimate) changed in the last 5000 years in the Southeastern United States (SE US). A hypothesis we sought to test was if hydroclimate had been predominantly controlled by the Pacific North American (PNA) pattern when it changed 4000 years before present (BP). Sediment sequences from two lakes in southern Alabama and Georgia (Buck and Halls) and one from northern Georgia (Pigeon Marsh) were collected and analyzed to establish if the records were suitable for further, high-resolution, in-depth study in a potential future proposal.

Halls only spanned 2100 years BP while Buck and Pigeon Marsh spanned the entire period of interest. We therefore established robust chronologies for both Buck and Pigeon Marsh and collected sediments from multiple locations throughout the lakes. At Buck, sediments were deposited continuously for the last 7000 years but there was a dramatic slowing down of sediment deposition from 2200-1100 years BP. At Pigeon Marsh, sediment deposition began at 11,400 years BP but was either intermittent or extremely slow until after 4500 years BP. Since Buck and Pigeon Marsh permitted the testing of our hypothesis, we undertook geochemical analysis of the organic matter and pollen down the length of the cores.

Given the changes in hydroclimate that occur in the modern-day at these two sites, when the PNA changes, we would expect to see opposing changes in the two locations. However, the data we generated do not support this hypothesis. Both Buck and Pigeon Marsh show signs of stability, or minimal change, in the lake environment across the transition in the PNA at 4000 years BP. There may be some preliminary evidence for the influence of the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) around 2000 years BP, but further support for conclusion would require more extensive work than we could complete here in this feasibility study that was funded solely for one year. The most profound period of change is the last several hundred years when all three lakes show marked changes in lake level and surrounding vegetation associated with European settlement.

Our results may suggest that future changes in the phase and strength of the PNA and NAO will play a minimal role in modulating hydroclimate in the SE US; however, additional records would be necessary to strengthen this conclusion. While our results were unexpected, this study fills in a major knowledge gap regarding Holocene past precipitation trends in the SE US.

The results of this project were communicated to the general public through a partnership with artist Rebecca Kamen in the “Pollen and Climate” art exhibit which will be permanently displayed at the Louisiana State University College of Sciences building.
